Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Amanda Haes of the University of Iowa will exploit the plasmonic properties of gold nanorods encapsulated in chromatographic-like silica membranes for selective transport and subsequent surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) detection of small molecules and anti-cancer drugs without the use of traditional receptor based surface chemistry. Importantly, the diffusion and transport of the target molecules will be systematically investigated using principles that typically guide chromatographic separations. SERS detection will be dictated via molecular diffusion and transport through the chromatographic-like silica membrane to the metal core of the solution-phase nanostructures and is expected to be promoted by the double layer thickness and charge states of the molecules and silica membranes. Direct molecular detection with (1) identification, (2) quantification, and (3) signal amplification vs. normal Raman signals are expected thereby opening up possibilities of trace drug and biomolecule detection. The broader impacts include mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students. New hands-on scientific activities for elementary students will be developed, reinforcing the excitement of chemistry in these young, impressionable students.

This work would advance general nanomaterials surface chemistry design strategies for understanding the transport and direct small molecule detection in complex sample matrices. The unique tunability of this surface chemistry modification approach could have significant impacts on applications of these materials in the fields of biomedical and environmental sensing as well as forensics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcomes of this project advanced fundamental knowledge and understanding related to the design, characterization, and implementation of metal nanoparticles for use in an optical detection technique called surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). These metal nanoparticles were coated in stabilizing layers composed of porous glass and polymers. By carefully considering how materials design influenced both the optical properties of the materials in harsh environments and the ability of molecules to be transported through the porous layers, several major outcomes resulted.

First, small defects and/or differences in the porous layers were shown to significantly influence the detectability of small molecules using SERS. New materials characterization techniques were utilized to overcome this challenge, thus resulting in reproducible detection and in batch to batch consistent and successful syntheses. Second, because these reproducibility challenges were addressed, the resulting materials were challenged with different molecules to better understand how molecule-molecule and molecule-metal interactions influenced SERS detection. Molecular compositions (functional groups) were shown to systematically influence how molecules interacted with each other and the metal. This resulted in a mechanistic understanding of how SERS signals arise from optically stable and uniformly encapsulated nanoparticles. Finally, a better understanding of how molecules were transported through the porous glass layer to the metal nanoparticles for SERS detection was formulated. Important parameters for understanding the energetics of this process included pore diameter and length, molecule charge and size, and solvent composition. These significant advances in nanomaterial design strategies are being and could be applied to solve important detection challenges in a variety of fields including biology, chemistry, dentistry, environmental science, forensics, and medicine.

In addition to these major scientific advances, many students and citizens were directly and positively impacted by this award. Students ranging in level from graduate, undergraduate, and high school were trained in safe chemical practices, nanoscience, and spectroscopy through this project. Experience working in a laboratory and learning to practice scientific principles learned in the classroom is an enriching yet intense and highly impactful opportunity. The research team members involved used the scientific method, interpreted results, shared these results through both oral and poster presentations, and disseminated these results through scientific publications. Finally, this project provided support to develop and carryout outreach activities at science museums and in several local school districts. The most notable of these resulted in the research team hosting over 650 fifth grade students from local school districts to the University of Iowa campus. These students visited several labs learning about science and engineering and worked in a laboratory to make lotion out of common household reagents. These new activities were aimed at developing an excitement for chemistry and reinforcing that science is fun with many exciting career options.
